Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Greywater Effluent Over Time and the Effect of Water Usage on Greywater Treatment

ProgramReference.Text: US CHINA COOP IN BASIC SCIENCE

POR.DRECONTENT:
In Beijing, China, water reuse practices have become a central issue in the water crises created by the burgeoning population and the limited water resources in the region. The Chinese government has responded with initiatives that emphasize urban water savings, pollution prevention and water reuse (Zhang et al, 2007). One potential water resource option being considered in China´s comprehensive development strategy is the treatment and reuse of greywater. Greywater (or grey wastewater) is defined as wastewater with lower levels of organic matter and nutrients in comparison to municipal wastewater. Contributions to greywater come from bathtubs, bathroom sinks, showers, washing machines and kitchen sinks. However, the feasibility of decentralized water recycling such as the use of greywater in Beijing entails considerable financial performance problems (Liang et al., 2008). Hence, research into greywater characteristics and technologies will be a valuable asset for China’s future.

The results of a thorough investigation into the current published literature related to standards for greywater infrastructure projects, showed a significant lack of information related to developing countries. China, as well as many other countries, currently have in use greywater recycling and reuse projects but lack government oversight and regulation. Although, the World Health Organization (WHO) has established generic protocol for policy development, many nations, including China, that are developing or pseudo-developed have not created regulations on greywater treatment and reuse specifically addressing the characterization of greywater after treatment or the optimization of treatment processes. A contributing factor to the difficulty of defining  greywater regulation has to do with the lack of predictive models  dealing specifically with greywater characterization and treatment.

Therefore, greywater treatment and reuse models are the next logical step to establishing appropriate regulations  for utilizing this valuable water resource. Schools like Tsingua University in Beijing China are leading the way in modeling water re-suse for small scale and municipal distribution networks. Research in this field is expected to open the possibility for the utilization of greywater resources in the future.
